Charter Day 2018

Building Berkeley

For our Charter Day issue, The Daily Californian has created an interactive map for readers to see the expansion of UC Berkeley since its founding in 1868.

By First Lastname and First Lastname
MARCH 23, 2017

The campus we know today is vastly different from its humble beginnings. In 1873, only two buildings comprised the campus — North and South Hall — one of which still stands today. Other buildings were not as lucky.

Scroll down to find our map detailing buildings and landmarks through the decades as they grew to become the campus we walk through every day. Pay special attention to when iconic structures like the Campanile and Sather Gate were erected, and see how old some of the classrooms you’re sitting in are.

Note: This map is not a comprehensive projection of every building to exist on campus — some have been left out for clarity.

The Original Campus - 1873

1873 - South Hall: First of two original buildings; cornerstone laid 1872.

1873 - North Hall: Razed in 1931. Site now occupied by Doe Library.

1870s

1879 - Mining and Mechanic Arts Building: Razed 1959 to clear site for Campbell Hall. Renamed Civil Engineering Building in 1907, and again renamed to Anthropological Museum in 1931.

1880s

1881 - Bacon Hall: Razed in 1961. Formerly known as Bacon Art and Library Building. Renamed in 1911. Razed to clear site for Birge Hall.

1885 - Anatomy Building: 1937. Formerly Metallurgical Laboratory. Renamed in 1907. Razed to clear site for Crocker Radiation Laboratory.

1888 - Agriculture Building: Razed in 1930. Rebuilt as Budd Hall in 1897 after it was destroyed by fire. Razed 1930 to clear site for Moses Hall.

1890s

1891 - Chemistry Building: Razed in 1963. Razed to clear site for Hildebrand Hall.

1893 - Mechanics Building: Renamed Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Building in 1931. Razed 1965 to clear site for Davis Hall addition.

1893 - Goldman School: Formerly Beta Theta Fraternity chapter house. University purchased in 1966, became Public Policy school in 1969, named Goldman in 1997.

1898 - Botany Building: Razin in 1930 as a fire hazard.

1898 - East Hall: Razed in 1942 as a fire hazard. First located on site of LeConte Hall, moved to site of Morrison Hall in 1921.

1898 - Hearst Hall: Destroyed by fire in 1922, now used for southern portion of Wurster Hall.

1898 - Psychology Building: Razed in 1930. Formerly Philosophy Building. Renamed in 1916. Razed as fire hazard.

1900s

1903 - Faculty Club

1903 - Hearst Greek Theatre

1904 - Anthropology Building: Razed in 1953 to clear site for Hertz Hall.

1904 - Architecture Building: Renamed Engineering Research Services Building in 1964.

1905 - California Hall

1906 - North Gate Hall

1906 - Senior Hall

1907 - Hearst Memorial Mining Building

1910s

1911 - Durant Hall: Formerly Boalt Hall of Law. Renamed in 1951.

1911 - University House: Formerly known as President’s House.

1912 - Agriculture Hall

1912 - Girton Hall

1912 - Wellman Hall

1912 - Julia Morgan Hall

1913 - Chemistry Auditorium: Razed in 1959 to clear site for Latimer Hall.

1913 - Sather Gate and Bridge

1914 - Sather Tower, as known as the Campanile

1917 - Doe Memorial Library

1917 - Gilman Hall

1917 - Wheeler Hall

1917 - Hilgard Hall

1920s

1920 - Military Science Building: Became Music Building in 1933, then Dwinelle Annex in 1958.

1922 - Social Welfare Building: Razed in 1953 to clear site for Alumni House.

1923 - Band Building: Razed in 1964 to improve pedestrian circulation.

1923 - Stephens Hall: Formerly Stephens Memorial Union.

1924 - Haviland Hall

1924 - Hesse Hall

1924 - Le Conte Hall

1927 - Botanical Gardens

1927 - Hearst Gymnasium for Women

1927 - Anna Head Alumnae Hall

1929 - Architects and Engineers Building: Formerly known as Grounds and Buildings Building. Renamed in 1961.

1929 - Bowles Hall

1930s

1930 - Giannini Hall

1930 - International House: Occupied by Navy V-12 units during World War II and called Callaghan Hall, returned to University 1946.

1930 - Life Sciences Building

1931 - Davis Hall: Formerly known as Engineering Materials Laboratory. Renamed in 1966.

1931 - Mclaughlin Hall: Formerly Engineering Building. Renamed in 1966.

1931 - Moses Hall: Formerly Eshleman Hall (1931-1964). Originally a publications building for "Daily Californian" and student magazines owned by ASUC.

1931 - Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

1937 - Crocker Radiation Laboratory: Razed twice — 1962 and 1966. First lab built specifically to house a cyclotron. East portion of building razed 1962 to clear site for Physical Sciences Lecture Hall; west portion razed to improve campus landscape.

1940s

1941 - Optometry Building: Formerly Emergency Classroom Building then Durant Hall.

1941 - Sproul Hall: Formerly Administration Building.

1941 - Minor Hall

1942 - Donner Laboratory

1942 - Stern Hall

1947 - Callaghan Hall

1948 - Lewis Hall

1948 - Mulford Hall: Formerly Forestry Building, renamed in 1964.

1949 - Bancroft Library

1950s

1950 - Cory Hall

1952 - Dwinelle Hall

1953 - Home Economics Building: Renamed Morgan Hall in 1962.

1953 - Morgan Hall

1954 - Alumni House

1954 - Giauque Hall

1955 - Warren Hall: Demolished and rebuilt at nearby location in 2005.

1957 - Pelican Building

1957 - Anthony Hall

1958 - Hertz Memorial Hall of Music

1958 - Morrison Hall

1959 - Campbell Hall

1959 - Haas Clubhouse

1959 - Kroeber Hall

1959 - University Hall

1959 - O'Brien Hall

1959 - Martin Luther King Jr. Student Union: Rebuilt in 2015.

1960s

1960 - Cesar E. Chavez Student Center

1961 - Earth Sciences Building

1961 - McCone Hall

1962 - Tolman Hall

1963 - Chemical Biodynamics Laboratory

1963 - Latimer Hall

1964 - Barrows Hall

1964 - Birge Hall

1964 - Wurster Hall

1964 - Barker Hall

1964 - Etcheverry Hall

1964 - Pimentel Hall

1965 - Eshleman Hall: Rebuilt in 2015.

1966 - Hildebrand Hall

1966 - Lawrence Hall of Science

1966 - Simon Hall

1967 - Evans Hall

1968 - Moffitt Undergraduate Library

1968 - Zellerbach Hall

1970s

1970 - Woo Han Fai Hall

1974 - Office of Public Affairs

1980s

1980 - Bechtel Engineering Center

1984 - Recreational Sports Facility

1990s

1990 - Koshland Hall

1993 - Tang Center

1994 - Soda Hall

1995 - Cheit Hall

1995 - Haas School of Business

1996 - Tan Hall

1999 - Haas Pavilion

2000s

2004 - Hargrove Music Library

2007 - Stanley Hall

2008 - Starr East Asian Library

2009 - Sutardja Dai Hall

Today

2010 - Blum Hall. Formerly Naval Architecture Building, built in 1914

2011 - Li Ka Shing Hall

2012 - Energy Biosciences Building

2015 - Jacobs Hall

2016 - Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive: Founded in 1963. Moved to new home in 2016.

About this story

Most data was collected from The Centennial Record of the University of California. This project also cited more recent structures from UC Berkeley’s Campus Map.

This project is open-source on GitHub.
